article.description: Surprise winners of the Big 12 regular season, the Oklahoma State Cowboys didn't let up in the conference tournament.
article.headline: Cowboys hold Texas scoreless for almost 14 minutes
article.linkText: Oklahoma St. captures first tourney title since '95
article.story: DALLAS (AP) -- When Oklahoma State's lead in the Big 12 tournament final was cut from 16 to three, the Cowboys were frustrated. Then, Texas forward Brian Boddicker sent Oklahoma State's Terrence Crawford flying into his bench. That made the Cowboys angry. Oklahoma State responded by holding the Longhorns without a field goal for nearly 14 of the final 15 minutes, sending them to a 65-49 victory Sunday that gave them the conference tournament championship to go with their regular-season title. "When players do that stuff to us, we tend to get feisty," forward Ivan McFarlin said. "We're all like brothers. If you do that to one of our brothers, we'll get mad." The runaway victory helped send the Cowboys (27-3) to the NCAA tournament with a second seed. They play Eastern Washington on Friday in Kansas City. Texas (23-7) still landed a No. 3 seed. The Longhorns will play Princeton on Thursday in Denver. While disappointed not to get a top seed -- especially with four of the six teams ranked ahead of them losing in recent days -- the Cowboys still matched the 1992 squad for best seed in school history. That's quite a feat for a team widely picked to finish fifth in the league as it tried blending three transfers and two holdovers. "They play so hard, a high level of intensity that shows up in loose balls, rebounds, hustle plays," coach Eddie Sutton said. "I'm not sure I've ever been prouder of a basketball team than this one. They'll always be very special." This game ended shortly before the seeds were announced. Tournament committee chairman Bob Bowlsby said the late starting time prevented the result from being factored into the decision. Big 12 commissioner Kevin Weiberg said the league will discuss a schedule change. Their contract with ESPN runs for four more years. Any adjustment would likely cost the Big 12 since the current setup makes this game highly rated. "We'd have to think it through," Weiberg said. "It's a risk-reward issue. I'm sure it will be a topic of much discussion and debate." Kansas and Texas Tech were the only other Big 12 teams invited to the tournament. The bubble burst for Colorado, Missouri and Oklahoma. This is only the third time in the league's eight-year history that one of its teams hasn't been a No. 1 seed. It's the second time only four teams made it. It's the first time both happened the same year. The Big 12 had six teams and two No. 1s last year. "I had some sense this could happen," said Weiberg, who was on the selection committee the last three years. "These things go in cycles. I understand that." Seventh-ranked Oklahoma State (27-3) opened the title game with tenacious defense, limiting the Longhorns to a blocked shot and five turnovers in one six-series span. That helped the Cowboys to an 18-2 run and, soon after, a 16-point lead. But the 11th-ranked Longhorns (23-7) got within 42-39 with 14:48 to play. On the Cowboys' ensuing possession, John Lucas III put up a 3-pointer and Boddicker and Crawford tangled going for the rebound. Sutton came away furious, as was the heavily pro-Cowboys crowd. When OSU's Tony Allen, the tournament MVP, was called for a foul away from the skirmish, emotions went soaring again. And the Longhorns wouldn't get another field goal until a putback by James Thomas with 57 seconds left got them within 16 at 63-47. A Final Four team when led by T.J. Ford last March, the Longhorns have lost three of their last five -- albeit twice to Oklahoma State -- and were down by 12 and 11 in the victories. "I'm just disappointed, really, with the way we started this whole tournament, in terms of early in games getting down and getting ourselves in holes and have to fight back," Texas coach Rick Barnes said. "Even with all of that, we put ourselves back in position to have a chance to win the game."
